{{About|the New Age movement and its spirituality|the astrological age in western astrology|Age of Aquarius|other uses with the term New Age}} [[File:Top of Atmosphere.jpg|thumb|right|260px|alt=White cloud tops below with Earth's azure atmosphere blending into outer space, where a thin crescent moon hovers against the darkness|New Age spirituality often makes references to mythological representations of the [[Earth]], [[Moon]], and [[outer space]]; the term ''New Age'' refers to the coming [[astrological age|astrological]] [[Age of Aquarius]].<ref name="JGMelton"/>]]
The '''New Age movement''' is a [[Western culture|Western]] [[spirituality|spiritual]] movement that developed in the second half of the 20th century. Its central precepts have been described as "drawing on both Eastern and Western spiritual and [[metaphysics|metaphysical]] traditions and infusing them with influences from [[self-help]] and motivational [[psychology]], [[holistic health]], [[parapsychology]], consciousness research and [[quantum physics]]".<ref>{{Harvnb |Drury|2004 | p=12}}</ref>
It aims to create "a spirituality without borders or confining dogmas" that is inclusive and [[religious pluralism|pluralistic]].<ref name="Drury 2004 8">{{Harvnb |Drury|2004 | p=8}}</ref> It holds to "a holistic worldview",<ref>{{Harvnb |Drury|2004 | p=11}}</ref> emphasising that the [[dialectical monism|Mind, Body and Spirit]] are interrelated<ref name="JGMelton">Melton, J. Gordon – Director Institute for the Study of American Religion. [http://web.archive.org/web/20060614001357/religiousmovements.lib.virginia.edu/nrms/newage.html New Age Transformed], retrieved 2006-06</ref> and that there is a form of [[monism]] and unity throughout the universe.<ref name="Langone">Michael D. Langone, Ph.D. Cult Observer, 1993, Volume 10, No. 1. [http://www.csj.org/rg/rgessays/rgessay_newage.htm What Is "New Age"?], retrieved 2006-07</ref> It attempts to create "a worldview that includes both science and spirituality"<ref>{{Harvnb |Drury|2004 | p=10}}</ref> and embraces a number of forms of [[mainstream science]] as well as other forms of science that are considered [[Fringe science|fringe]].
The origins of the movement can be found in Medieval [[astrology]] and [[alchemy]], such as the writings of [[Paracelsus]], in Renaissance interests in [[Hermeticism]], in 18th century [[mysticism]], such as that of [[Emanuel Swedenborg]], and in beliefs in [[animal magnetism]] espoused by [[Franz Mesmer]]. In the 19th and early 20th centuries, authors such as [[Godfrey Higgins]] and the esotericists [[Eliphas Levi]], [[Helena Blavatsky]], and [[George Gurdjieff]] articulated specific histories, cosmologies, and some of the basic philosophical principles that would influence the movement. It experienced a revival as a result of the work of individuals such as [[Alice Bailey]] and organizations such as the [[Theosophical Society]]. It gained further momentum in the 1960s, taking influence from [[metaphysics]], [[perennial philosophy]], self-help [[psychology]], and the various Indian gurus who visited the West during that decade.<ref>{{Harvnb |Drury|2004 | pp=8–10}}</ref> In the 1970s, it developed a social and political component.<ref name=Mayne />
The New Age movement includes elements of older spiritual and religious traditions ranging from [[monotheism]] through [[pantheism|classical pantheism]], [[naturalistic pantheism]], [[pandeism]], [[panentheism]], and [[polytheism]] combined with [[science]] and [[Gaia philosophy]]; particularly [[archaeoastronomy]], [[astronomy]], [[ecology]], [[environmentalism]], the [[Gaia hypothesis]], [[psychology]] and [[physics]].
New Age practices and philosophies sometimes draw inspiration from major [[major religious groups|world religions]]: [[Buddhism]], [[Taoism]], [[Chinese folk religion]], [[Christianity]], [[Hinduism]], [[Islam]] (especially [[Sufism]]), [[Judaism]] (especially [[Kabbalah]]), [[Sikhism]]; with strong influences from [[East Asian religions]], [[Gnosticism]], [[Neopaganism]], [[New Thought]], [[Spiritualism]], [[Theosophy]], [[Universalism]] and [[Western esotericism]].<ref>{{Harvnb |Lewis|1992 | pp=15–18}}</ref> The term ''New Age'' refers to the coming [[astrological age|astrological]] [[Age of Aquarius]].<ref name="JGMelton"/>
==History==
===Origins=== The author [[Nevill Drury]] claimed there are "four key precursors of the New Age," who had set the way for many of its widely held precepts.<ref name="Drury 2004 8"/> The first of these was [[Emanuel Swedenborg]] (1688–1772), a Swedish scientist who after a religious experience devoted himself to [[Christian mysticism]], believing that he could travel to [[Heaven]] and [[Hell]] and commune with angels, demons and spirits, and who published widely on the subject of his experiences. The second person was [[Franz Mesmer]] (1734–1815), who had developed a form of healing using magnets, believing that there was a force known as "[[animal magnetism]]" that affected humans. The third figure was the Russian [[Helena Blavatsky]] (1831–1891), one of the founders of the [[Theosophical Society]], through which she propagated her religious movement of [[Theosophy]], which itself combined a number of elements from Eastern religions like [[Hinduism]] and [[Buddhism]] with Western elements. The fourth figure was [[George Gurdjieff]] (c. 1872–1949), who founded the philosophy of the [[Fourth Way]], through which he conveyed a number of spiritual teachings to his disciples. A fifth individual whom Drury identified as an important influence upon the New Age movement was the Indian [[Swami Vivekananda]] (1863–1902), an adherent of the philosophy of [[Vedanta]] who first brought Hinduism to the West in the late 19th century.<ref>{{Harvnb |Drury|2004 | pp=27–28}}</ref>
The term ''New Age'' was used as early as 1809 by [[William Blake]] who described a coming era of spiritual and artistic advancement in his [[preface]] to ''[[Milton a Poem]]'' by stating: "... when the New Age is at leisure to pronounce, all will be set right ..."<ref name="Milton">{{Citation|last1=Blake|first1=William|last2=Sampson|first2=John|editor=John Sampson|title=The Poetical Works of William Blake: Including the Unpublished French Revolution; Together with the Minor Prophetic Books and Selections from the Four Zoas, Milton and Jerusalem|url=http://books.google.com/?id=uWblZFfnZEsC&pg=PA369&dq=Milton+%22New+Age%22#v=onepage&q=Milton%20%22New%20Age%22&f=false|accessdate=2010-10-05|year=2006|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|location=Whitefish, Montana, US|isbn=978-1-4286-1155-9|page=369|chapter=Selections from ''Milton''}}</ref>
Some of the New Age movement's constituent elements appeared initially in the 19th-century [[metaphysics|metaphysical]] movements: [[Spiritualism]], [[Theosophy]], and [[New Thought]] and also the alternative medicine movements of [[chiropractic]]s and [[naturopathy]].<ref name="JGMelton"/><ref name="Langone"/> These movements have roots in [[Transcendentalism]], [[Mesmerism]], [[Swedenborgianism]], and various earlier Western [[esoteric]] or [[occult]] traditions, such as the [[Hermeticism|hermetic]] arts of astrology, [[magic (paranormal)|magic]], [[alchemy]], and [[Kabbalah]]. The term ''New Age'' was used in this context in [[Madame Blavatsky]]'s book ''[[The Secret Doctrine]]'', published in 1888.<ref name="Spencer">{{Citation|last=Spencer|first=Neil|title=True as the Stars above: Adventures in Modern Astrology|publisher=Victor Gollancz|year=2000|pages=115–27|isbn=0-575-06769-1}}</ref>
A weekly journal of [[Liberal Christianity|Christian liberalism]] and [[socialism]] titled ''[[The New Age]]'' was published as early as 1894;<ref>[http://www.modjourn.org/render.php?id=mjp.2005.00.001&view=mjp_object General Introduction to ''The New Age'' 1907–1922], Brown University & The University of Tulsa—The Modernist Journals Project, retrieved 2010-10-28</ref> it was sold to a group of socialist writers headed by [[Alfred Richard Orage]] and [[Holbrook Jackson]] in 1907. Contributors included [[H. G. Wells]], [[George Bernard Shaw]], and [[William Butler Yeats]]; the magazine became a forum for [[politics]], [[literature]], and [[the arts]].<ref>''Modernism In and Beyond the “Little Magazines”'', Winter 2007, Professor Ann Ardis, Brown University</ref><ref>[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9057250/Alfred-Richard-Orage#143390.hook "The New Age" Encyclopædia Britannica article on Orage]</ref> Between 1908 and 1914, it was instrumental in pioneering the British [[avant-garde]] from [[Vorticism]] to [[Imagism]]. Orage met [[P. D. Ouspensky]], a follower of Gurdjieff, in 1914 and began correspondence with [[Harry Houdini]]; he became less interested in literature and art with an increased focus on [[mysticism]] and other spiritual topics; the magazine was sold in 1921. According to [[Brown University]], ''The New Age'' "... helped to shape modernism in literature and the arts from 1907 to 1922."<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.brown.edu/Administration/News_Bureau/2006-07/06-143.html|title=Modernist Journals Project Has Grant to Digitize Rare Magazines|date=2007-04-19|publisher=Brown University|accessdate=2009-02-20}}</ref>
===Development=== [[File:Stonehenge Distance.jpg|thumb|right|200px|alt=Stonehenge with trimmed green grass on a partly-sunny day|[[Stonehenge]] and other ancient sites are revered by many who practice New Age spirituality.]]
Popularisation behind these ideas has roots in the work of early 20th century writers such as [[D. H. Lawrence]] and [[William Butler Yeats]]. In the early- to mid-1900s, American mystic, theologian, and founder of the [[Association for Research and Enlightenment]] [[Edgar Cayce]] was a seminal influence on what later would be termed the ''New Age movement''; he was known in particular for the practice some refer to as ''[[mediumship|channeling]]''.<ref>{{Citation|title=The Emerging Network: A Sociology of the New Age and Neo-Pagan Movements|first=Michael|last=York|year=1995|page=60|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=0-8476-8001-0}}</ref> The psychologist [[Carl Jung]] was a proponent of the concept of the Age of Aquarius.<ref>{{Citation|last=Stein|first=Murray|title=Transformation |publisher=Texas A & M University Press|year=2005|page=138|isbn=1-58544-449-9|url=http://books.google.com/?id=uZK_clekR9gC&pg=PA138&lpg=PA138&dq=Carl+Gustav+Jung+++Age+of+Aquarius}}</ref> In a letter to his friend Peter Baynes, dated 12 August 1940, Jung wrote a passage: "... This year reminds me of the enormous earthquake in 26 B.C. that shook down the great temple of [[Karnak]]. It was the prelude to the destruction of all temples, because a new time had begun. 1940 is the year when we approach the meridian of the first [[star]] in [[Aquarius (constellation)|Aquarius]]. It is the premonitory earthquake of the New Age ..."<ref>Letters of C. G. Jung: Volume I, 1906–1950, p. 285</ref><ref name="Jung letter">{{Citation|last=Dunne|first=Claire|title=Carl Jung: Wounded Healer of the Soul: An Illustrated Biography|url=http://books.google.com/?id=uegLZklR0fEC&pg=PA126&dq=It+is+the+premonitory+earthquake+of+the+New+Age#v=onepage&q=premonitory%20earthquake%20of%20the%20New%20Age&f=false|accessdate=2010-10-04|edition=Illustrated (2003)|year=2000|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|location=London, UK|isbn=978-0-8264-6307-4|page=126|chapter=Visions}}</ref> Former Theosophist [[Rudolf Steiner]] and his [[Anthroposophy|Anthroposophical movement]] are a major influence. [[Neo-Theosophy|Neo-Theosophist]] [[Alice Bailey]] published the book ''Discipleship in the New Age'' (1944), which used the term ''New Age'' in reference to the transition from the [[astrological age]] of [[Pisces (astrology)|Pisces]] to [[Aquarius (astrology)|Aquarius]]. While claims of racial bias in the writings of Rudolf Steiner and Alice Bailey were made,<ref name="Shnirelman">''Acta no. 13, Analysis of Current Trends in Antisemitism''. The Vidal Sassoon International Center for the Study of Antisemitism at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. 1998. [http://sicsa.huji.ac.il/13shnir.html Shnirelman, Victor A. ''Russian Neo-pagan Myths and Antisemitism''], retrieved 2007-08-22</ref> Bailey was firmly opposed to the [[Axis powers]]; she believed that [[Adolf Hitler]] was [[demonic possession|possessed]] by the ''Dark Forces'',<ref>Bailey, Alice A. ''The Externalisation of the Hierarchy'' New York:1957 Lucis Publishing Co. p. 425</ref> and Steiner emphasized [[racial equality]] as a principle central to anthroposophical thought and [[human]]ity's progress.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.skepticreport.com/sr/?p=480|title=The racial Teachings of Rudolf Steiner|accessdate=2007-04-11|last=Hansson|first=Sven Ove|authorlink=Sven Ove Hansson|date=2005-06-01|work=|publisher=SkepticReport|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Anthroposophie und die Rassismus-Vorwürfe|pages=309ff|isbn=978-3-924391-24-9|language=German|author=mit einem Vorwort von Justus Wittich und einer Analyse nach deutschem Recht von Ingo Krampen ; die Überarbeitung in deutscher Sprache wurde von der Kommission "Anthroposophie und die Frage der Rassen" autorisiert ; Übersetzung: Ramon Brüll.|year=2000|publisher=Info3-Verlag|location=Frankfurt am Main}}</ref> Any racial elements from these influences have not remained part of the [[Anthroposophical Society]] as contemporary adherents of the society have either not adopted or repudiated these beliefs.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.info3.de/ycms/artikel_190.shtml|title=Commission on "Anthroposophy and the Question of Race"|accessdate=2007-09-22|last=Kerkvliet|first=Von Gerard|publisher=Anthroposophical Society in The Netherlands |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070625132217/http://www.info3.de/ycms/artikel_190.shtml |archivedate = June 25, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.anthroposophy.org/Gov/StatementOnDiversity.php|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080106140711/http://www.anthroposophy.org/Gov/StatementOnDiversity.php|archivedate=2008-01-06|title=Position Statement on Diversity|accessdate=2007-04-12|last=|first=|date=|year=1998|month=|work=|publisher=The General Council of the Anthroposophical Society in America|pages=|quote=We explicitly reject any racial theory that may be construed to be part of Rudolf Steiner's writings. The Anthroposophical Society in America is an open, public society and it rejects any purported spiritual or scientific theory on the basis of which the alleged superiority of one race is justified at the expense of another race.}}</ref> Another early usage of the term, was by the American artist, mystic, and philosopher [[Walter Russell]], who spoke of "... this New Age philosophy of the spiritual re-awakening of man ... Man's purpose in this New Age is to acquire more and more knowledge ..." in his essay "Power Through Knowledge," which was also published in 1944.<ref>(The University of Science and Philosophy). [http://www.philosophy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4&Itemid=1 "Power Through Knowledge"], retrieved 2010-10-12</ref>
===Contemporary usage of the term=== [[File:Barrel House.jpg|thumb|right|200px|alt=Wooden barrel house in forest with surrounding footpaths|This barrel house was the first dwelling constructed at the [[Findhorn Ecovillage]].]]
The [[subculture]] that later became known as ''New Age'' already existed in the early 1970s, based on and adopting ideas originally present in the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture]] of the 1960s. Two entities founded in 1962: the [[Esalen Institute]] in [[Big Sur]], [[California]] and the [[Findhorn Foundation]]—an [[intentional community]] which continues to operate the [[Findhorn Ecovillage]] near [[Findhorn]], [[Moray]], [[Scotland]]—played an instrumental role during the early growth period of the New Age movement.<ref name="Findhorn">{{Harvnb |Hanegraaff|1996 | pp=38–39}}</ref>
Widespread usage of the term ''New Age'' began in the mid-1970s (reflected in the title of monthly periodical ''[[New Age Journal]]'') and probably influenced several thousand small metaphysical book- and gift-stores that increasingly defined themselves as "New Age bookstores."<ref>{{Citation|title=Fifty Years Among the New Words: A Dictionary of Neologisms, 1941–1991|first=John|last=Algeo|coauthors=Adele S. Algeo|year=1991|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=234|isbn=0-521-44971-5}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Modernist Alchemy: Poetry and the Occult|first=Timothy|last=Materer|year=1995|publisher=Cornell University Press|page=14|isbn=0-8014-3146-8 }}</ref> As a result of the large-scale activities surrounding the [[Harmonic Convergence]] in 1987, the American mass-media further popularised the term as a label for the alternative spiritual subculture, including practices such as [[meditation]], [[Channeling (mediumistic)|channeling]], [[crystal healing]], [[astral projection]], [[psychic]] experience, [[holistic health]], [[simple living]], and [[environmentalism]]; or belief in phenomena such as [[Earth mysteries]], [[ancient astronauts]], [[extraterrestrial life]], [[unidentified flying object]]s, [[crop circle]]s, and [[reincarnation]]. Several New Age publications appeared by the late 1980s such as ''Psychic Guide'' (later renamed ''Body, Mind & Spirit''), ''Yoga Journal'', ''New Age Voice'', ''New Age Retailer'', and ''NAPRA ReView'' by the New Age Publishers and Retailers Alliance.
Several key events occurred, which raised public awareness of the New Age subculture: the production of the musical ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair: The American Tribal Love-Rock Musical]]'' (1967) with its opening song "[[Aquarius/Let the Sunshine In|Aquarius]]" and its memorable line "''This is the dawning of the Age of Aquarius''";<ref>{{Harvnb |Hanegraaff|1996 | pp=10–11}}</ref> publication of [[Linda Goodman]]'s best-selling astrology books ''Sun Signs'' (1968) and ''Love Signs'' (1978); the release of [[Shirley MacLaine]]'s book ''[[Out on a Limb (Shirley MacLaine book)|Out on a Limb]]'' (1983), later adapted into a television mini-series with the same name (1987); and the "[[Harmonic Convergence]]" [[planetary alignment]] on August 16 and 17, 1987,<ref>{{Harvnb |Hanegraaff|1996 | p=335}}</ref> organized by [[José Argüelles]] at [[Sedona, Arizona|Sedona]] in the U.S. state of [[Arizona]]. The claims of channelers [[Jane Roberts]] ([[Seth Material]]), [[Helen Schucman]] (''[[A Course in Miracles]]''), [[J. Z. Knight]] ([[Ramtha]]), [[Neale Donald Walsch]] (''[[Conversations with God]]'') (note that Walsch denies being a "channeler" and his books make it obvious that he is not one, though the text emerged through a dialogue with a deeper part of himself in a process comparable to automatic writing), and [[Rene Gaudette]] (The Wonders) contributed to the movement's growth.<ref>{{Harvnb |Lewis|1992 | pp=22–23}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb |Drury|2004 | pp=133–34}}</ref> Relevant New Age works include the writings of [[James Redfield]], [[Eckhart Tolle]], [[Barbara Marx Hubbard]], [[Christopher Hills]], [[Marianne Williamson]], [[Deepak Chopra]], [[John Holland (psychic)|John Holland]], [[Gary Zukav]], [[Wayne Dyer]], and [[Rhonda Byrne]].
While [[J. Gordon Melton]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Melton|first=J. Gordon |authorlink=J. Gordon Melton|title=New Age Encyclopaedia|publisher=Routledge |year=1989|isbn=0-8103-7159-6|isbn-status=May be invalid - please double check}}</ref> [[Wouter Hanegraaff]],<ref>{{Harvnb |Hanegraaff|1996 | pp=1ff}}</ref> and [[Paul Heelas]] <ref>{{Citation|last=Heelas|first=Paul|authorlink=Paul Heelas|title=The Spiritual Revolution: Why Religion is Giving Way to Spirituality (Religion and Spirituality in the Modern World)|publisher=WileyBlackwell|year=2004|isbn=1-4051-1959-4|isbn-status=May be invalid - please double check }}</ref> have emphasised personal aspects, [[Mark Satin]],<ref name=Satin /> [[Theodore Roszak (scholar)|Theodore Roszak]],<ref name=Roszak /> [[Marilyn Ferguson]],<ref name=Ferguson /> and [[Corinne McLaughlin]] <ref name=McLaughlin /> have described New Age as a values-based sociopolitical movement.
==Spirituality== {{Main|Spirituality|List of New Age topics}} {{See also|Outline of spirituality|List of philosophies}}
While the New Age lacks any unified belief-system, many spiritual practices and philosophies feature commonly among adherents of the movement—sometimes referred to as ''New Agers''.
{| class="wikitable" |+ [[Philosophy]] and [[cosmology]] ! Concept !! Description |- | [[Theism]] || General and abstract idea of [[God]], understood in many ways and seen as superseding the need to anthropomorphize deity. |- | [[Spirit|Spiritual beings]] || Many believe that [[deity|gods]], [[Deva (New Age)|devas]], [[angel]]s, [[Ascended Master]]s, [[elemental]]s, [[ghost]]s, [[faeries]], [[Spirit guide]]s and [[extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrials]] can [[spirit guide|spiritually guide]] people who open themselves to such guidance.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.ascendedmasters.ac/index.html|title=Ascended Masters Research Center|accessdate=2001-07-01}}</ref> |- | [[Afterlife]] || The New Age sets no restrictions on one's beliefs about an afterlife.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} Each person can find their own path - whether it involves [[reincarnation]], non-existence, or a higher [[Plane (esotericism)|plane]] of consciousness. Some believe consciousness persists after death as life in different forms; the afterlife exists for further learning through the form of a [[spirit]], [[reincarnation]] and/or [[near-death experience]]s.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.near-death.com/experiences/reincarnation02.html|title=Reincarnation and NDE Research|accessdate=2006-10-01|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060809081101/http://www.near-death.com/experiences/reincarnation02.html|archivedate=2006-08-09}}</ref> The New Age belief in reincarnation can differ from the [[Buddhist]] or [[Hindu]] concepts: seeing a soul, for example, born into a spiritual realm or even on a far-away planet, and there is no desire to end this process; there are also beliefs that either all individuals (not just a minority) can choose where they reincarnate, or that God/the universe always chooses the best reincarnation for each person.<ref>[http://www.patheos.com/Library/New-Age/Beliefs/Afterlife-and-Salvation.html New Age Afterlife and Salvation], [[Patheos]] online library</ref> There may be a belief in a limited number of earthly lives which are followed by some guaranteed higher existence. One version is that the individual must incarnate once under each of the twelve signs of the zodiac.<ref>The Secret Language of Birthdays. Goldschneider, Elffers</ref> There may be a belief in [[hell]], but typically not in the traditional [[Hell in Christian beliefs|Christian sense]] or [[Jahannam|Islamic sense]] of eternal damnation. [[Universalist]] views of the afterlife are common. |- | [[Age of Aquarius]] || Some astrologers{{which|date=December 2010}} regard the current time-period{{when|date=January 2012}} as the dawning of the Age of Aquarius, correlated to various changes in the world; and some claim that the early 1960s was the actual beginning of the Age of Aquarius, though this claim is highly contentious. Common claims about the developments associated with the Age of Aquarius include, but are not limited to, [[human rights]], [[democracy]], innovative technology, [[electricity]], computers, and aviation. Esoteric claims are that the Age of Aquarius will see a rise in consciousness.<ref name="Spencer"/> |- | [[Eschatology]] || Related to the above; a belief that we are living on the threshold of a great change in human consciousness usually focused on the date December 21, 2012 when a major, usually positive, change is anticipated.<ref name="skepsis">{{cite web|author=Sacha Defesche|title='The 2012 Phenomenon': A historical and typological approach to a modern apocalyptic mythology.|year=2007|publisher=skepsis|url=http://skepsis.no/?p=599|accessdate=April 29, 2011}}</ref> See [[2012 phenomenon]]. |- | [[Astrology]] || [[Horoscope]]s and the [[Zodiac]] are used in understanding, interpreting, and organizing information about personality, human affairs, and other terrestrial matters.<ref>{{Harvnb |Lewis|1992 | pp=187–88}}</ref> |- | [[Teleology]] || Life has a purpose; this includes a belief in [[synchronicity]]—that coincidences have spiritual meaning and lessons to teach those open to them. Everything is [[universalism|universally connected]] through God and participates in the same [[Energy (esotericism)|energy]].<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.onlygodexists.org/|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060804182335/http://www.onlygodexists.org/|archivedate=2006-08-04|title=Only God Exists|accessdate=2006-07-01}}</ref> There is a cosmic goal and a belief that all entities are (knowingly or unknowingly) cooperating towards this goal. |- | [[Indigo children]] || Children are being born with a more highly developed spiritual power than earlier generations.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0511/15/lad.02.html|title=CNN News transcript of interview with Sandy Bershad, an Indigo Child|date=2005-11-15|publisher=Cable News Network|accessdate=2009-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.greatdreams.com/indigo.htm|title=Indigo Children – Crystalline Children|work=Awakening-Healing News|date=2002-06-04|accessdate=2006-10-01|isbn=1-56414-948-X}}</ref> |- | [[Interpersonal relationship]]s || Opportunities to learn about one's self and relationships are [[destiny|destined]] to be repeated until they are healthy.<ref>Rudhyar, Dane. Chapter 6: The Time For Mutation is Now. ''Directives for New Life''</ref> Those in the New Age movement accept [[Women’s equality|women's complete equality]] in all aspects of society including religion and the complete acceptance of one's [[sexual orientation]], whether [[heterosexual]], [[homosexual]] ([[gay]] or [[lesbian]]) or [[bisexual]] and [[gender identity]], whether [[cisgender]], [[transgender]], or [[intersexual]] as a means of spiritual development. |- | [[Intuition (knowledge)|Intuition]] || An important aspect of perception – offset by a somewhat strict [[rationalism]] – noted especially in the works of psychologist [[Carl Jung]].<ref name="Intuition">{{Harvnb |Hanegraaff|1996 | pp=217–24}}</ref> |- | [[Optimism]] || Positive thinking supported by [[affirmations (New Age)|affirmations]] will achieve success in anything,<ref>The Salem New Age Center. Salem, Massachusetts, US. [http://www.salemctr.com/newage/center32.html Supercharged Affirmations], retrieved 2007-08</ref> based on the concept that Thought Creates. Therefore, as one begins focusing attention and consciousness on the positive, on the "half-filled" glass of water, reality starts shifting and materializing the positive intentions and aspects of life. ==Lifestyle== [[File:Geograph 6oct09 014.JPG|thumb|right|200px|alt=New Age store along stone street with bicycles parked out front and large crystals behind display windows|New Age shop in St Albans, UK]]
New Age spirituality has led to a wide array of literature on the subject and an active niche market, with books, music, crafts, and services in alternative medicine available at New Age stores, [[fair]]s, and [[festival]]s.<ref name="Montana">{{Citation|title=Alternative medicine: from New Age to mainstream|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/54102508.html|author=University of Montana|publisher=Montana Business Quarterly|date=Winter 1998}}{{dead link|date=June 2012}}</ref><ref name="Heelas-Altmed">{{Citation|title=The New Age Movement: Religion, Culture and Society in the Age of Postmodernity|last=Heelas|first=Paul|year=1996|page=116|publisher=Blackwell Publishing|isbn=0-631-19332-4}}</ref>
===Demographics=== People who practice New Age spirituality or who embrace its [[Lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] are included in the ''Lifestyle of Health and Sustainability'' ([[LOHAS]]) demographic [[market segment]], currently in a growth phase, related to [[sustainable living]], green ecological initiatives, and generally composed of a relatively affluent and well-educated segment.<ref name="Moore">{{Citation|url=http://www.medialifemagazine.com/news2002/jun02/jun17/1_mon/news3monday.html|title=Body & Soul, yoga w/o the yoyos|author=David Moore|date=2002-06-17|publisher=Media Life}}</ref><ref name="Pubweekly">{{Citation|last=Rosen|first=Judith|title=Crossing the Boundaries:Regardless of its label, this increasingly mainstream category continues to broaden its subject base|date=2002-05-27|publisher=Publishers Weekly|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA219343.html|archiveurl=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA219343.html|archivedate=2010-10-29}}{{dead link|date=June 2012}}</ref> The LOHAS market segment in 2006 was estimated at [[United States dollar|USD$]]300 billion, approximately 30 percent of the United States consumer market.<ref>{{Citation|last=Cohen|first=Maurie J.|date=2007-01|title=Consumer credit, household financial management, and sustainable consumption|journal=International Journal of Consumer Studies|volume=31|issue=1|pages=57–65|doi=10.1111/j.1470-6431.2005.00485.x}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Halweil|first=Brianink|coauthors=Lisa Mastny, Erik Assadourian, Linda Starke, Worldwatch Institute|title=State of the World 2004: A Worldwatch Institute Report on Progress Toward a Sustainable Society|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|year=2004|page=167|isbn=0-393-32539-3}}</ref> According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', a study by the Natural Marketing Institute showed that in 2000, 68 million Americans were included within the LOHAS demographic. The sociologist Paul H. Ray, who coined the term ''[[Cultural Creatives]]'' in his book ''[[The Cultural Creatives: How 50 Million People Are Changing the World]]'' (2000), states, "What you're seeing is a demand for products of equal quality that are also virtuous."<ref name="LOHAS">{{Citation|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E01E3D8103CF933A15754C0A9659C8B63|title=Business; They Care About the World (and They Shop, Too)|last=Cortese|first=Amy|date=2003-07-20|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|pages=|accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref><ref name="Gourmet">{{Citation|url=http://www.gourmetretailer.com/gourmetretailer/magazine/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1738479#|title=Understanding the LOHAS Lifestyle|last=Everage|first=Laura|date=2002-10-01|work=The Gourmet Retailer Magazine|publisher=The Nielsen Company|pages=|accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref>
The New Age is strongly gendered; sociologist Ciara O'Connor argues that it shows a tension between commodification and women's empowerment.<ref>O'Connor, Ciara, "Becoming whole: an exploration of women's choices in the holistic and New Age movement in Ireland". 220–39 in Olivia Cosgrove et al. (eds), Ireland's new religious movements. Cambridge Scholars, 2011</ref>
===Community=== {{Further|Sustainability}} {{See also|List of intentional communities}} [[File:Sustainable development.svg|right|thumb|alt=Three intersecting circles representing economy, society and environment showing how sustainability involves cooperation at the point where they all intersect.|Definitions of sustainability often refer to the "three pillars" of social, environmental, and economic sustainability.<ref name=Adams2006>Adams, W.M. (2006). [http://cmsdata.iucn.org/downloads/iucn_future_of_sustanability.pdf "The Future of Sustainability: Re-thinking Environment and Development in the Twenty-first Century."] Report of the IUCN Renowned Thinkers Meeting, 29–31 January 2006, retrieved 2009-02-16</ref>]]
Some New Agers advocate living in a [[Simple living|simple]] and [[Sustainable living|sustainable]] manner to reduce humanity's impact on the [[natural resource]]s of Earth; and they shun [[consumerism]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Spring|first=Joel H.|title=How Educational Ideologies Are Shaping Global Society: Intergovernmental Organizations, NGO's, and the Decline of the Nation-state|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates|location=Mahwah, New Jersey, US|year=2004|edition=illustrated|page=119|chapter=Chapter 4: Love the Biosphere: Environmental Ideologies Shaping Global Society|isbn=0-8058-4915-7|url=http://books.google.com/?id=8Xssc9_3FPgC&pg=PA119&dq=%22Sustainable+living%22+new+agers#PPA119,M1|archiveurl=http://books.google.com/?id=8Xssc9_3FPgC&pg=PA119&dq=%22Sustainable+living%22+new+agers#PPA119,M1|accessdate=2009-03-27|archivedate=2010-10-29}}</ref><ref>Satin (1978), p. 199.</ref> The New Age movement has been centered around rebuilding a [[sense of community]] to counter [[social disintegration]]; this has been attempted through the formation of [[intentional communities]], where individuals come together to live and work in a communal lifestyle.<ref>{{Harvnb |Lewis|1992 | pp=200–01}}</ref>
===Holistic health=== {{See also|List of branches of alternative medicine}} Practitioners of New Age spirituality may use [[alternative medicine]] in addition to or in place of conventional [[medicine]];<ref name="Heelas-Altmed"/><ref name="Butler 2007">Butler, Jenny and Maria Tighe, "Holistic Health and New Age in the British Isles". 415-34 in Kemp, Daren and Lewis, James R., ed. (2007), Handbook of New Age, Boston, Massachusetts, US: Brill Academic Publishers, ISBN 90-04-15355-1</ref><ref>{{Citation|url=http://nccam.nih.gov/|title=National Centre for Complementary and Alternative Medicine|accessdate=2006-06-01}}</ref> while some conventional [[physician]]s have adopted aspects or the complete approach of [[holistic health]]. The mainstreaming of the Holistic Health movement in the UK is discussed by Maria Tighe. The inter-relation of holistic health with the New Age movement is illustrated in Jenny Butler's<ref name="Butler 2007"/> ethnographic description of "Angel therapy" in the Republic of Ireland.
===Music=== {{See also|List of New Age music artists|List of ambient artists}} [[New Age music]] is peaceful music of various styles intended to create inspiration, relaxation, and positive feelings while listening. Studies have determined that New Age music can be an effective component of [[stress management]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Principles and Practice of Stress Management, Third Edition|last=Lehrer|first=Paul M.|coauthors=David H. (FRW) Barlow, Robert L. Woolfolk, Wesley E. Sime|year=2007|pages=46–47|isbn=1-59385-000-X|publisher=Guilford Press|location=New York}}</ref>
The style began in the 1970s with the works of free-form jazz groups recording on the [[ECM (record label)|ECM]] label; such as Oregon, the [[Paul Winter Consort]], and other pre-ambient bands; as well as [[ambient music]] performer [[Brian Eno]] and classical avant-garde musician [[Daniel Kobialka]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} In the early 1970s, it was mostly instrumental with both acoustic and electronic styles. New Age music evolved to include a wide range of styles from electronic [[space music]] ([[Constance Demby|like Constance Demby's]]) using [[synthesizer]]s and acoustic instrumentals using [[Native American flute]]s and [[drum]]s, [[singing bowl]]s, and [[world music]] sounds to spiritual [[chant]]ing from other cultures.
==Reception==
===Organized religion=== {{Further|Comparative religion}} Mainstream religious institutions have been critical of New Age spirituality. Author Johanna Michaelson published her own experiences with various New Age practices in ''The Beautiful Side of Evil'' (1982); after concluding these activities were [[demon]]ic, she [[Conversion to Christianity|converted]] to Christianity.<ref>{{Citation|last1=Martin|first1=Walter R.|authorlink1=Walter Ralston Martin|last2=Martin Rische|first2=Jill|last3=Van Gorden|first3=Kurt|title=The Kingdom of the Occult|url=http://books.google.com/?id=n1qaOUDfCeEC&pg=PA241&dq=%22Johanna+Michaelson%22#v=onepage&q=%22Johanna%20Michaelson%22&f=false|accessdate=2010-11-08|year=2008|publisher=Thomas Nelson|location=Nashville, Tennessee, US|isbn=1-4185-1644-9|pages=241–42}}</ref> Michigan attorney and activist [[Constance Cumbey]] offered the first major criticism of the New Age movement from a Christian perspective in ''The Hidden Dangers of the Rainbow: The New Age Movement and Our Coming Age of Barbarism'' (1983).<ref>{{Harvnb |Lewis|1992 | pp=154–56}}</ref>
The [[Roman Catholic Church]] published ''[[A Christian reflection on the New Age]]'' in 2003, following a six-year study; the 90-page document criticizes New Age practices such as [[yoga]], [[meditation]], [[feng shui]], and [[crystal healing]].<ref name="BBC Vatican">{{Citation|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2722743.stm|title=Vatican sounds New Age alert|date=2003-02-04|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2010-10-27}}</ref><ref>''Handbook of vocational psychology'' by W. Bruce Walsh, Mark Savickas 2005 ISBN 0-8058-4517-8 p. 358</ref> According to the Vatican, euphoric states attained through New Age practices should not be confused with prayer or viewed as signs of God's presence.<ref name="NY Times Vatican">{{Citation|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE1D61531F934A35752C0A966958260&sec=&spon=|title=Trying to Reconcile the Ways of the Vatican and the East |last=Steinfels|first=Peter|date=1990-01-07|work=New York Times|accessdate=2008-12-05}}</ref> Cardinal [[Paul Poupard]], then-president of the [[Pontifical Council for Culture]], said the "New Age is a misleading answer to the oldest hopes of man."<ref name="BBC Vatican"/> Monsignor [[Michael L. Fitzgerald|Michael Fitzgerald]], then-president of the [[Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue]], stated at the Vatican conference on the document: the "Church avoids any concept that is close to those of the New Age."<ref name="Holy See">{{Citation|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/pontifical_councils/interelg/documents/rc_pc_interelg_doc_20030203_press-conf-new-age_en.html|title=Presentations of Holy See's Document on "New Age"|last=Fitzgerald|first=Michael L.|coauthors=Paul Poupard|year=2003|work=Jesus Christ the Bearer of the Water of Life: a Christian Reflection on the "New Age"|publisher=Roman Catholic Church|accessdate=2010-11-06|location=Vatican City}}</ref>
Expressing agreement with the Vatican's position, [[Richard Land]] of the [[Southern Baptist Convention]] stated that many Baptists would regard New Age ideas as contrary to Christian tradition and doctrine.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/feb/08/local/me-relignewage8/2|title=New Age Beliefs Aren't Christian, Vatican Finds|last=Stammer|first=Larry B.|date=February 8, 2003|work=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Tribune Company|accessdate=2010-10-04|location=Los Angeles, California, US}}</ref>
===Integral theory=== {{Further|Integral Theory}} The author [[Ken Wilber]] posits that most New Age thought falls into what he termed the ''[[pre/trans fallacy]]''.<ref name="Wilber1">{{Citation|last=Wilber|first=Ken|title=The Collected Works of Ken Wilber|publisher=Shambhala Publications|location=Boston, MA, US|year=1999|volume=3|chapter=Introduction to the Third Volume|isbn=1-59030-321-0|url=http://wilber.shambhala.com/html/books/cowokev3_intro.cfm/|accessdate=2009-06-12 }}</ref> According to Wilber, human [[developmental psychology]] moves from the pre-personal, through the personal, then to the transpersonal (spiritually advanced or enlightened) level.<ref name="Wilber2">{{Harvnb |Hanegraaff|1996 | p=250}}</ref> He regards 80 percent of New Age spirituality as pre-rational (pre-conventional) and as relying primarily on mythic-magical thinking; this contrasts with a post-rational (including and transcending rational) genuinely [[worldcentrism|world-centric]] consciousness.<ref name="Wilber1"/><ref name="Wilber2"/> Despite his criticism of most New Age thought, Wilber has been categorized as New Age due to his emphasis on a [[transpersonal]] view,<ref>[[Wouter J. Hanegraaff]], ''New Age Religion and Western Culture'', SUNY, 1998, pp.70 (''"Ken Wilber [...] defends a transpersonal worldview which qualifies as 'New Age'"'').</ref> and more recently, as a philosopher.<ref>Marian de Souza (ed.), ''International handbook of the religious, moral and spiritual dimensions in education.'' Dordrecht: Springer 2006, p. 93. ISBN 978-1-4020-4803-6.</ref>
===Indigenous peoples of the Americas=== {{Further|Indigenous peoples of the Americas}} Some adherents of traditional disciplines, such as the [[Lakota people]]—a tribe of the indigenous peoples of the Americas, reject "the expropriation of [their] ceremonial ways by non-Indians." They see the New Age movement as either not fully understanding, deliberately trivializing, or distorting their disciplines.<ref name="Fenelon1998">{{Citation|last=Fenelon|first=James V.|title=Culturicide, resistance, and survival of the Lakota ("Sioux Nation")|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=DYDeLzTyWQQC&lpg=PA297&pg=PA297 |accessdate=2009-03-16|year=1998|publisher=Taylor & Francis|location=New York|isbn=0-8153-3119-3|pages=295–97}}</ref>
They have coined the term ''plastic medicine men'' to describe individuals, from within their own communities "who are prostituting our spiritual ways for their own selfish gain, with no regard for the spiritual well-being of the people as a whole."<ref name="Fenelon1998"/> The term ''[[plastic shaman]]'' has been applied to outsiders who identify themselves as shamans, holy people, or other traditional spiritual leaders, but who have no genuine connection to the traditions or cultures they claim to represent.
The academic [[Ward Churchill]] criticized the New Age movement as an instrument of [[cultural imperialism]] that is exploitative of indigenous cultures by reducing them to a commodity to be traded. In ''Fantasies of the Master Race'', he criticized the [[cultural appropriation]] of Native American culture and symbols in not only the New Age movement, but also in [[art]] and [[popular culture]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Fantasies of the Master Race: Literature, Cinema and the Colonization of American Indians|last=Churchill|first=Ward|authorlink=Ward Churchill|year=1992|publisher=Common Courage Press|location=|isbn=0-9628838-7-5|page=304}}</ref> However, many of Churchill's allegations and research findings have been called into question by other academics, leading to an [[Ward Churchill academic misconduct investigation|academic misconduct investigation]] and subsequent firing by the University of Colorado at Boulder.
===Goddess movement=== {{Further|Goddess movement}} Followers of the Goddess movement have severely criticized the New Age as fundamentally [[patriarchal]], analytical rather than intuitive, and as supporting the status quo, particularly in its implicit gender roles. [[Monica Sjöö]] (1938–2005) wrote that New Age channelers were virtually all women, but the spirits they purported to channel, offering guidance to humanity, were nearly all male. Sjöö was highly critical of [[Theosophy]], the [["I AM" Activity]], and particularly [[Alice Bailey]], whom she saw as promoting [[Nazi]]-like Aryan ideals. Sjöö's writings also condemn the New Age for its support of communication and information processing technologies which, she believes, may produce harmful [[Electromagnetic radiation and health|low-level electromagnetic radiation]].<ref>Sjöö, Monica (1998).Bristol, England: Green Leaf Bookshop. ''[http://monicasjoo.org/books/naessay/newageessay1.htm New Age Channelings - Who Or What Is Being Channeled?]'', retrieved 2010-06-28</ref><ref>Sjöö, Monica. Notes and explanations to accompany ''Return of the Dark/Light Mother''. Originally appeared in ''From the Flames, Radical Feminism with Spirit'', Issue 22 (Winter 1998/99). ''[http://monicasjoo.org/artic/channelbrief/sinisterchannelings1.htm# Sinister Channelings]'', retrieved 2010-06-28</ref><ref>Sjöö, Monica (1999-09-09). ''Return of the Dark/Light Mother or New Age Armageddon? Towards a Feminist Vision of the Future''. Texas: Plain View Press</ref>
===Academia=== In the 2003 book ''[[A Culture of Conspiracy: Apocalyptic Visions in Contemporary America]]'' written by [[Michael Barkun]], professor emeritus of [[political science]] at the [[Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs]]<ref name="Barkun 2003">{{Cite book| author = Barkun, Michael | title = A Culture of Conspiracy: Apocalyptic Visions in Contemporary America | publisher = University of California Press; 1 edition | year = 2003 | isbn = 0-520-23805-2}}</ref> Barkun argues New age beliefs have been greatly facilitated by the advent of the internet which has exposed people to beliefs once consigned to the outermost fringe of political and religious life. He identifies two trends which he terms, " the rise of improvisational [[millennialism]]" and "the popularity of [[social stigma|stigmatized]] knowledge". He voices concern that these tends could lead to [[mass hysteria]] and could have a devastating effect on American political life.
==Social and political movement==
While many commentators have focused on the personal aspects of the New Age movement, it also has a social and political component. The New Age political movement became visible in the 1970s, peaked in the 1980s, and continued into the 1990s.<ref name=Kyle>Kyle, Richard G. (Autumn 1995). "The Political Ideas of the New Age Movement". ''Journal of Church and State'', pp. 831–48. Alternate version in Kyle, Richard (1994). ''The New Age Movement in American Culture''. University Press of America, pp. 113–31. ISBN 978-0-7618-0010-1.</ref> In the 21st century, the political movement evolved in new directions.

Although these books, periodicals, and organizations did not speak with one voice, commentators found that many of them sounded common themes:
* Our world does not reflect who we at our best can be.<ref name=Wasserman />
* All our most significant social and political problems go back at least 300 years.<ref name=Slaton>Slaton, Christa Daryl; Woolpert, Stephen; Schwerin, Edward W. (1998). "Introduction: What Is Transformational Politics?" In Woolpert, Stephen; Slaton, Christa Daryl; and Schwerin, Edward W., eds. (1998). ''Transformational Politics: Theory, Study, and Practice''. State University of New York Press, pp. xix–xxiii. ISBN 978-0-7914-3945-6.</ref>
* The political system therefore needs to be transformed, not just reformed,<ref name=Kyle /> with the help of a new political theory appropriate to our time.<ref name=Cloud />
* Holism – seeing everything as connected – is the first step on the way to creating that new political theory.<ref name=Kyle /><ref name=Wasserman />
* Doing away with the categories of "left" and "right" is another essential part of that task.<ref name=Kyle /><ref name=Wasserman />
* Significant social change requires deep changes in consciousness; institutional change is not enough.<ref name=Cloud /><ref name=Boggs>Boggs, Carl (2000). ''The End of Politics''. Guilford Press, pp. 169–73. ISBN 978-1-57230-504-5.</ref>
* Above all, consciousness needs to become more ecologically aware,<ref name=Wasserman /><ref name=Chandler /> more feminist,<ref name=Wasserman /><ref name=Chandler /> and more oriented to compassionate global unity.<ref name=Kyle /><ref name=Chandler />
* Desirable values include nonviolence, diversity, a sense of community, and a sense of enoughness.<ref name=Chandler /><ref name=McClaughry />
* Human growth and development, not economic growth, should be the overarching goal of New Age society.<ref name=McClaughry />
* Ownership and control of institutions is important. But the size of institutions is at least as important. We must move away from big governments, big corporations, and other large institutions to the extent it enhances our lives.<ref name=Kyle /><ref name=McClaughry />
* We can begin this process by interlacing hierarchical structures with horizontal networks.<ref name=Chandler /><ref name=Lipnack>Lipnack, Jessica; Stamps, Jeffrey (1982). ''Networking: The First Report and Directory''. Doubleday and Company, Chap. 6. ISBN 978-0-385-18121-1.</ref>
*Global unification is a key goal, but is probably best accomplished by networking at many levels rather than establishing a centralized world state.<ref name=Kyle />
* The agent of political change is no longer the working class, or any economic class. Instead, it is all those who are developing themselves personally and spiritually – all who aspire to live lives of dignity and service.<ref name=Cloud />
* Evolution is to be preferred to revolution. However, the forces of evolutionary change need not be a statistical majority. A "critical mass" of informed, committed, and spiritually aware people can move a nation forward.<ref name=Kyle /><ref name=Clark />
Over time, these themes began to cohere. By the 1980s, observers in both North America<ref name=Wasserman /><ref name=Boggs /> and Europe<ref>Jamison, Andrew (2001). ''The Making of Green Knowledge: Environmental Politics and Cultural Transformation''. Cambridge University Press, p. 5. ISBN 978-0-521-79252-3.</ref><ref>Zizek, Slavoj (2000). ''The Ticklish Subject: The Absent Centre of Political Ontology''. Verso Books, pp. 1–2. ISBN 978-1-85984-291-1.</ref> were acknowledging the emergence of a New Age political "ideology".
===Political objections at century’s end===
Toward the end of the 20th century, criticisms were being directed at the New Age political project from many quarters,<ref>Sessions, George (23 September 1987). "[http://www.clas.ufl.edu/users/bron/re/Sessions--deandnewage7(8)27(sep87).pdf Deep Ecology and the New Age]". ''Earth First! Journal'', pp. 27–30. [[Deep ecology|Deep ecologist]] says New Age politics is too enamored of high technology, space exploration, and computer management systems. Accessed 15 September 2012.</ref><ref>Weigel, George (March 1989). "No Options". ''American Purpose'', vol. 3, no. 3, pp. 21–22. [[Conservatism in the United States|Mainstream conservative]] says New Age politics is just a retooled version of leftism.</ref> but especially from the liberal left and religious right.
On the left, scholars argued that New Age politics is an oxymoron: that personal growth has little or nothing to do with political change.<ref>Jamison (2001), cited above, p. 169.</ref><ref>Zizek (2000), cited above, pp. 1–2 and 70.</ref> One political scientist said New Age politics fails to recognize the "realities" of economic and political power;<ref name=Boggs /> another faulted it for not being opposed to the capitalist system, or to liberal individualism.<ref name=Cloud /> Antinuclear activist [[Harvey Wasserman]] argued that New Age politics is too averse to social conflict to be effective politically.<ref name=Wasserman />
On the right, some worried that the drive to come up with a new consciousness and new values would topple time-tested old values.<ref name=Groothuis /> Others worried that the celebration of diversity would leave no strong viewpoint in place to guide society.<ref name=Groothuis /> The passion for world unity – one humanity, one planet – was said to lead inevitably to the centralization of power.<ref>LaHaye, Tim; Hindson, Ed (2001). ''Seduction of the Heart: How to Guard and Keep Your Heart from Evil''. W Publishing Group / Thomas Nelson, Inc., p. 178. ISBN 978-0-8499-1726-4.</ref><ref>Rhodes, Ron (1995). ''New Age Movement''. Zondervan Publishing House, p. 20. ISBN 978-0-310-70431-7.</ref> Some doubted that networking could provide an effective counterweight to centralization and bureaucracy.<ref name=Chandler />
Neither left nor right was impressed with the New Age's ability to organize itself politically.<ref name=Wasserman /><ref name=Clark /> Many explanations were offered for the New Age's practical political weakness. Some said that the New Age political thinkers and activists of the 1970s and 1980s were simply too far in advance of their time.<ref>Ray and Anderson (2000), cited above, pp. 206–07.</ref> Others suggested that New Age activists' commitment to the often frustrating process of consensus decision-making was at fault.<ref name=Clark /> After it dissolved, New World Alliance co-founder Marc Sarkady told an interviewer that the Alliance was too "New Age counter-cultural" to appeal to a broad public.<ref>Gottlieb (1987), cited above, p. 153.</ref>
===New directions in the 21st century===
[[File:America Speaks event - Flickr - Knight Foundation.jpg|thumb |right |alt=Dozens of people talking at tables in a large room. |[[AmericaSpeaks]] event, 2011. In the 21st century, organizations like AmericaSpeaks embodied the approach of listening to and learning from everyone.]]
In the 21st century, writers and activists continue to pursue a political project with New Age roots. However, it differs from the project that had come before, in part as a result of learning from the criticisms that had been directed at the earlier wave of New Age political actors.
The principal difference was anticipated in texts like ''New Age Politics'' author [[Mark Satin]]'s essay "Twenty-eight Ways of Looking at Terrorism" (1991),<ref>Satin, Mark (1991). ''New Options for America: The Next American Experiment Has Begun''. Foreword by Marilyn Ferguson. The Press at California State University / Southern Illinois University Press, Chap. 19. ISBN 978-0-8093-1794-3.</ref> [[Human Potential Movement|human potential movement]] historian [[Walter Truett Anderson]]'s essay "Four Different Ways to Be Absolutely Right" (1995),<ref>Anderson, Walter Truett, ed. (1995). "Four Different Ways to Be Absolutely Right". In Anderson, Walter Truett, ed. (1995). ''The Truth About the Truth: De-Confusing and Re-Constructing the Postmodern World''. A Jeremy P. Tarcher Putnam Book / G. P. Putnam’s Sons, Chap. 18. ISBN 978-0-87477-801-4.</ref> and mediator Mark Gerzon's book ''A House Divided'' (1996).<ref>Gerzon, Mark (1996). ''A House Divided: Six Belief Systems Struggling for America's Soul''. A Jeremy P. Tarcher Putnam Book / G. P. Putnam’s Sons. ISBN 978-0-87477-823-6.</ref><ref>As shown above, the Satin text was published in a book foreworded by [[Marilyn Ferguson]], and the Anderson and Gerzon texts were published under the imprint of Ferguson's publisher, [[Jeremy P. Tarcher Inc.]]</ref> In these texts, the New Age political perspective is recognized as legitimate. But it is presented as merely one among many, with strong points and blind spots just like all the rest. The result was to alter the nature of the New Age political project. If every political perspective had unique strengths and significant weaknesses, then it no longer made sense to try to convert everyone to the New Age political perspective, as had been attempted in the 1970s and 1980s. It made more sense to try to construct a higher political synthesis that took every poliical perspective into account, including that of the New Age.<ref>McLaughlin (1993), cited above, p. 81 (quoting Satin).</ref><ref>Gerzon (1996), cited above, Chaps. 7–8.</ref>
Many 21st century books have attempted to articulate foundational aspects of this approach to politics and social change. They include [[Ken Wilber]]'s ''A Theory of Everything'' (2001),<ref name=Wilber>Wilber, Ken (2000). ''A Theory of Everything: An Integral Vision for Business, Politics, Science, and Spirituality''. Shambhala Publications. ISBN 978-1-57062-724-8.</ref> [[Mark Satin]]'s ''Radical Middle'' (2004),<ref name=Mark>Satin, Mark (2004). ''Radical Middle: The Politics We Need Now''. Westview Press and Basic Books. ISBN 978-0-8133-4190-6.</ref> [[David Korten]]'s ''The Great Turning'' (2006),<ref>Korten, David C. (2006). ''The Great Turning: From Empire to Earth Community''. ''Integral Consciousness and the Future of Evolution: How the Integral Worldview Is Transforming Politics, Culture, and Spirituality''. Paragon House. ISBN 978-1-55778-867-2.</ref> [[Marilyn Hamilton]]'s ''Integral City'' (2008),<ref name=Hamilton>Hamilton, Marilyn (2008). ''Integral City: Evolutionary Intelligences for the Human Hive''. New Society Publishers / Douglas & McIntyre. ISBN 978-0-86571-629-2.</ref> and Carter Phipps's ''Evolutionaries'' (2012).<ref name=Phipps>Phipps, Carter (2012). Another difference between the two eras of political thought is that, in the 21st century, few political actors use the term "New Age" or even "post-New Age"<ref name=Britannica>Melton, John Gordon (2012). "New Age Movement". In Encyclopedia Britannica (2012). ''Encyclopedia Britannica Online''. Encyclopedia Britannica Inc. Retrieved 30 August 2012.</ref> to describe themselves or their work. Some observers attribute this to the negative connotations that the term "New Age" had acquired.<ref name=Ray /><ref name=Britannica /> Instead, other terms are employed that connote a similar sense of personal and political development proceeding together over time. For example, according to an anthology from three political scientists, many writers and academics use the term "transformational" as a substitute for such terms as New Age and new paradigm.<ref name=Slaton /> [[Ken Wilber]] has popularized use of the term "integral",<ref name=Wilber /> Carter Phipps emphasizes the term "evolutionary",<ref name=Phipps /> and both terms can be found in some authors' book titles.<ref name=McIntosh /><ref name=Hamilton />
